Overview¶

This repository contains two adaptive numerical algorithms which use the Ogata quadrature method for applications to CSS TMD physics. The adaptive integration is optimized for integrals of the following form:

\[\begin{align} W_\nu(q_\perp;\vec{\alpha}) = \int_0^{\infty} \frac{db_\perp}{2\pi} b_\perp^{\nu+1} \widetilde{W}(b_\perp,\vec{\alpha}) J_\nu(b_\perp q_\perp). \end{align}\]

Where \(\vec{\alpha}\) contains external kineamtic parameters and \(\widetilde{W}(b_\perp,\vec{\alpha})\) is taken to be analytic close the the real axis and have a single peak at \(b_\perp>0\).

We denote the first Ogata quadrature method the ‘untransformed adaptive Ogata’ (agogu) and the second the ‘transformed adaptive Ogata’ (agogt). The untransformed Ogata quadrature is given by

\[\begin{align} W_\nu(q_\perp;\vec{\alpha}) \approx \frac{h}{2\pi}\frac{1}{q^{\nu+2}}\sum_{k = 1}^{N}\omega_{\nu k}x_{\nu k}^{\nu+1} \widetilde{W}(\frac{b_\perp}{q_\perp},\vec{\alpha}) J_\nu(x_{\nu k}). \end{align}\]

The transformed quadrature sum is given by

\[\begin{align} W_\nu(q_\perp;\vec{\alpha}) \approx \frac{1}{2}\frac{1}{q^{\nu+2}}\sum_{k = 1}^{N} \omega_{\nu k} \psi'(x_{\nu k}) (\frac{\pi}{h}\psi(x_{\nu k}))^{\nu+1} \widetilde{W}(\frac{\pi}{h q_\perp}\psi(x_{\nu k}),\vec{\alpha}) J_\nu(\frac{\pi}{h}\psi(x_{\nu k})) \end{align}\]

Here

\[\begin{align} w_{\nu k} = \frac{2}{\pi^2 \xi_{\nu |k|}J_{\nu+1}(\pi\xi_{\nu |k|})}\;, \qquad x_{\nu k} = h \xi_{\nu k}\; , \qquad J_{\nu}(\pi \xi_{\nu k}) = 0\; . \end{align}\]

and \(h\) and \(N\) are the optimized parameters. See directed publication for specific details.
